# Assessment

 + **Workshops** 5% Total (10 to complete, worth 0.5% each) Students must attend at least 7 out of the 10 workshops)
 + **Assignments** 55% Total (5 to complete worth 10%) Each assignment will also contain a peer review aspect (worth 1%) students must complete the peer review coursework component of the assignments to be awarded their associated peer reviewed grade
 + **Final Exam** 40% Total
 + Throughout the course there will also be the options to complete additional assignments/tasks for extra credit (capped at 5% in total)

#  Recommended texts

STATISTICAL METHODS IN BIOLOGY: Design and Analysis of Experiment and Regression, by Welham , Gezan , Clark & Mead, Published Oct 2014 
  + e-copy available from the library

MODERN STATISTICS FOR MODERN BIOLOGY , Susan Holmes, Wolfgang Huber, 2018

  + Website: http://web.stanford.edu/class/bios221/book/
  + e-copy also available [http://web.stanford.edu/class/bios221/book/](http://web.stanford.edu/class/bios221/book/)

##  Timetable (topics approx.)

+ **Lectures:** Thursdays 2–4pm
+ **Workshops** Fridays 2–3pm

| Week  | Overview  | Lecture | Workshop |
|---    |---        |---      |---       |
|  1    | R & RStudio catch up  | 4th March *optional* | 5th March *optional* |
|  2    | Data wrangling and visualisation. Intro to experimental design | 11th | 12th |
|  3    | Pairwise and multiple comparison procedures | 18th | 19th|
|  4    | Multiple comparison and resampling procedures   | 25th | 26th |
|  5    | Resampling procedures: randomisation, permutation, and bootstrapping  | 1st April | Good Friday |
|  | **Midterm break  5th--16th April** | | |
